propositions.text: The telephone rings, signaling a terrible change.
The narrator is not a fortune teller and cannot predict the future.
The narrator's father is dying.
The narrator fears losing his father and facing life alone at twenty-eight.
The narrator is an only child; his mother died two years ago.
The narrator returned home tired and couldn't sleep well.
The narrator leans forward, wishing the ringing would stop.
The family dog, Olson, senses the significance of the call.
Olson is an unusual dog, staring intently at people.
Olson may see something unsettling but is not easily frightened.
Olson is the narrator's dog and trusted friend.
The narrator finally answers the phone on the seventh ring.
A nurse from Mercy Hospital informs him of his father's critical condition.
The narrator is advised to go to the hospital immediately.
After hanging up, Olson rests his head on the narrator's lap.
The narrator feels a loss of sensation and an inability to think or act.
The silence of the house is oppressive.
The narrator calls Sasha Gude to drive him to the hospital.
Sasha usually sleeps until 8 PM and works as a radio DJ from midnight to 6 AM.
The narrator feels guilty about waking her on a March evening.
Sasha is also a friend the narrator can rely on.
Sasha answers on the second ring, sounding awake.
Sasha expresses regret, seemingly anticipating the bad news.
The narrator forces himself not to think about what might happen, hoping for a misdiagnosis or remission.
The narrator believes in miracles, considering his own survival to twenty-eight a miracle.
The narrator believes everyone 'needs a miracle'.
Sasha promises to be there in five minutes.
Walking to the hospital would be too conspicuous and risky at this hour.
The narrator asks Sasha to be careful and says he needs ten minutes to prepare.
They exchange 'I love you'.
The narrator describes California pepper trees.
During the day, they shimmer and appear graceful.
At night, they appear to bow their heads in sadness.
These trees line the long driveway to Cork's Funeral Home.
The funeral home is on a three-acre hill northeast of town.
The trees act as mourners.
The narrator climbs the private road, with landscape lights casting rings of light.
The wind rustles the leaves with a sigh.
No cars are parked along the road, indicating no services are in progress.
The narrator usually walks or bikes and has no reason to learn to drive.
Driving during the day is problematic, and at night, headlights are blinding without sunglasses, which draw police attention.
A full moon rises.
The narrator likes the moon for its gentle light.
The road loops around the hilltop, forming a circular lawn.
In the center of the lawn is a concrete cast of Michelangelo's 'Pietà'.
Under the moonlight, the sculpture gleams, making the crude casting appear less so.
The narrator appreciates humanity's ability to find solace and hope in even flawed things.
The narrator hesitates at the porch, unsure of what lies ahead.
The funeral home is a large, two-story Georgian-style building.
It looks out of place in Moonlight Bay.
Sandy Cork lives on the second floor, which is dark.
The viewing room is on the first floor, with faint light visible through stained glass.
The narrator rings the doorbell.
Sandy Cork emerges, his elegant gait suggesting his identity.
Sandy opens the door and lights the interior and porch.
Sandy expresses surprise at seeing Christopher.
Sandy offers condolences for the narrator's father.
Sandy assures the narrator his father was treated with extra care.
Sandy recalls taking a 20th-century poetry class from the narrator's father and learning to appreciate poets like Eliot and Pound.
The narrator mentions his father's favorite poets: Wallace Stevens, Donald Justice, and Louise Glück.
Sandy turns off the lights to be considerate.
Sandy states that while this is hard, at least the father is free from pain.
Sandy's green eyes appear dark under the moonlight.
The narrator asks to see his father.
Sandy expresses regret, stating the process has already begun.
The narrator asks if his father has been cremated.
Sandy confirms the body has been moved for cremation.
The narrator questions if it's too soon.
Sandy explains that delays are not wise in their business.
Sandy expresses distress at the narrator's sadness and wishes he could help.
The narrator feels ashamed of Sandy's lie, considering it a shared disgrace.
The narrator avoids Sandy's gaze and looks at the floor.
Sandy misinterprets the narrator's silence as grief and pats his shoulder.
Sandy admits he's not good at providing comfort and doesn't know how to make death easier.
The narrator forces himself to say he'll be fine and leaves before acting impulsively.
Sandy states he avoids clichés and only says special things to the narrator.
The narrator thanks Sandy and apologizes for the intrusion.
Sandy wishes the narrator had called earlier so he could have 'delayed' things.
The narrator reassures Sandy it's not his fault.
The narrator retreats from the porch and turns away from Sandy.
Sandy asks about funeral arrangements.
The narrator says he hasn't thought about it and will tell him tomorrow.
Sandy asks if the narrator is alright.
The narrator replies numbly that he's fine and will be alright.
The narrator walks away, looking back at the funeral home.
The 'Pietà' sculpture gleams under the moonlight.
The narrator resists the urge to look back at Sandy.
The trees whisper as he walks down the driveway.
The temperature drops, and a clean breeze blows from the sea.
Once out of Sandy's sight, the narrator looks back and sees only the roof and chimney against the starry sky.
He leaves the asphalt for the grass and heads uphill.
The funeral home's circular drive and the 'Pietà' reappear.
Sandy is inside, and the main door is closed.
The narrator goes around to the back of the house, using trees and bushes for cover.
The backyard features a large porch, a swimming pool, a Spanish-style courtyard, and a rose garden, hidden from public view.
The narrator notes the city's birth and death rates and the limited number of funeral homes.
Cork Funeral Home handles a significant portion of the business.
Death is a profitable business for Sandy.
The daytime view from the courtyard is presumably impressive.
Seeing no one in the lighted window, the narrator crosses the courtyard.
The moonlight shines on the dark pool water.
The house is adjacent to a large L-shaped garage, which houses two hearses and Sandy's car, and also contains the crematorium.
The narrator sneaks behind the garage, moving along the shorter side, with eucalyptus trees providing cover.
The air is fragrant with eucalyptus, and fallen leaves crunch underfoot.
The narrator knows Moonlight Bay well, especially this area.
He anticipates seeing something disturbing and horrific at the crematorium window.
His prediction proves correct.
Fifteen years prior, the narrator and his friend Bobby Heigeway explored the funeral home, fascinated by death.
They fantasized about finding gruesome things, like skeletons or a mad scientist son creating lightning.
They may have expected to encounter Lovecraftian deities in the rose garden.
Bobby called them 'weird kids', but the narrator felt they were only slightly weirder than others.
Bobby believed in embracing their strangeness and aligning with nature.
One October night, they found the crematorium window and were drawn by the flickering light.
Unable to see from their height, they moved a wooden bench to stand on.
They clearly saw Frank Cork and his assistant working, as the louvers were not fully closed.
Despite the risk of blindness, the narrator wanted to share the experience with Bobby.
A stretcher with an old man's body was near the window, his face visible.
The man's appearance suggested he died after a long illness.
His appearance was terrifying, making him a subject for their morbid fascination.
The most striking feature was his one open eye, filled with blood.
The eye seemed to stare into them.
They watched Frank and his assistant prepare the crematorium, noting the heat and their sweaty appearance.
The boys shivered despite the mild October night.
The funeral director pulled back the sheet, revealing the old man's emaciated body.
The boys were shocked but also thrilled, comparing it to watching 'Night of the Living Dead'.
As the body was placed in a cardboard box and pushed into the crematorium's blue flames, the boys held onto each other.
They feared being pulled into the fire themselves.
The heavy thud of the crematorium door closing echoed through them.
They returned the bench and fled the funeral home.
They hid in the unlit bleachers of a high school football field.
They ate chips and drank cola, exclaiming how cool the experience was.
They compared it to other exciting but less intense experiences.
The narrator reflects on how bold thirteen-year-olds can be.
The experience solidified their friendship.
They sensed a deeper meaning to the event beyond their comprehension.
A second, more disturbing event in December cemented their bond.
Fifteen years later, the narrator is back at the crematorium window.
The louvers are still yellowed, but the gaps are wide enough to see through.
Sandy Cork and his assistant are working next to the 'Power Pak II' cremator.
They are wearing masks, gloves, and disposable aprons.
An opaque nylon body bag contains a homeless man, likely to be cremated in place of the narrator's father.
The man's face is severely beaten, and his eyes are missing.
This sight is far more horrifying than the bleeding eye of the old man from fifteen years ago.
The previous incident represented nature's cruelty; this represents human cruelty.
In the past, they occasionally returned to the window, smelling the eucalyptus and associating it with death.
Frank Cork cremated only three out of fourteen bodies during those months.
Most bodies were embalmed for traditional burial.
They couldn't observe the embalming room as it was in the basement and had no windows.
The narrator is privately relieved they couldn't witness embalming.
Frank likely did embalming during the day and cremations at night.
The old cremator was primitive, but the 'Power Pak II' is more advanced.
Frank chose nighttime cremations out of respect for the families, to avoid them seeing the smoke from afar.
Bobby's father, the editor of the Moonlight Bay Gazette, provided them with information on recent deaths.
They would rush to the funeral home to observe cremations.
Mr. Gables, president of First National Bank, died of a heart attack and was cremated.
Henry Ames, a carpenter, fell and broke his neck, and was also cremated, but they didn't witness it because the louvers were closed.
They witnessed the cremation of Roberta Aikens, a thirty-year-old librarian and mother of a five-year-old son.
Roberta looked beautiful and serene on the stretcher.
They felt no carnal thoughts, only admiration for her beauty.
She died quickly from a ruptured brain aneurysm.
Her face was peaceful, with a slight smile, as if dreaming.
When the sheet was lifted, they saw her slender, perfectly formed body, described as indescribably lovely and beyond carnal attraction.
She looked young and timeless.
The funeral home personnel were unusually gentle and reverent as they placed her in the cremation box.
Frank Cork removed his gloves and wiped his eyes, not from sweat.
Unlike previous cremations where they chatted, Frank and his assistant were silent.
The boys were also speechless.
They returned the bench and left the funeral home quietly.
They rode their bikes to the beach.
The beach was deserted under the winter sky.
The narrator thought about Christmas approaching and the orphaned son of Roberta Aikens.
Bobby suggested they go swimming.
Despite the mild weather, the December sea was cold.
They swam far out into the ocean.
They swam north with the tide, a dangerous distance.
They were both good swimmers but became careless due to the perceived warmth of the water.
The cold water became increasingly intense.
They should have returned to shore but instead paused.
They began to shiver violently, their breath chilling their throats.
They turned back, still far from shore.
Their limbs grew heavy, and their hearts pounded.
The waves felt rough and biting.
They kept each other in sight, relying on their friendship for support.
They returned to shore exhausted, nauseated, and shivering.
They were too cold to even remember the crematorium's heat.
They left the beach and rode their bikes home.
They slept deeply upon returning home.
They never returned to the crematorium window or mentioned Roberta Aikens again.
They remained steadfast friends, willing to die for each other.
The narrator reflects on the unreality of sensory experiences compared to abstract concepts like love, friendship, and loneliness.
The current reality of the crematorium window and its sights is more real than imagined.
The brutal murder of a hitchhiker and the gouging out of his eyes are disturbingly real.
The motive of a body swap is questioned, as is the reason for removing the eyes.
The narrator describes a burly man with a shaven head, a pearl earring, and cold, steely eyes.
This man seems capable of inflicting pain and dismemberment without remorse.
Sandy and his assistant are pushing the gurney towards the cremator when the phone rings.
The narrator instinctively shrinks away from the window, feeling like he triggered an alarm.
He sees Sandy take off his mask and answer the phone, his tone shifting from confusion to anger.
Sandy slams the receiver back, likely deafening the person on the other end.
Sandy speaks urgently to his assistant, and the narrator thinks he hears his name mentioned negatively.
The assistant, Jesse Pinne, has a gaunt face, red hair, and brown eyes.
Jesse begins to zip up the body bag.
Sandy takes off his jacket and reveals a shoulder holster with a handgun.
Sandy yells at Jesse and gestures towards the window.
The narrator believes he hasn't been seen.
Despite his optimism, the narrator decides it's wiser to flee.
He retreats through the gap between the garage wall and eucalyptus trees, the air thick with the scent of death.
The crunching of leaves underfoot is masked by the wind in the trees.
The narrator suspects the call was from a hospital orderly who discovered the body swap and saw the narrator's wallet.
Sandy now realizes the narrator's presence at the door had a different motive.
Sandy and Jesse will likely search for him nearby.
The narrator reaches the backyard and decides not to linger near the house or driveway.
He runs across the lawn towards the rose garden.
The rose garden is terraced, with trellises and winding paths.
Roses are in bloom, their dark colors appearing black in the moonlight.
White flowers resemble baby heads.
Voices are heard, and two flashlight beams emerge from near the garage.
Sandy Cork, likely armed, and Jesse Pinne are searching.
A third, fourth, fifth, and sixth flashlight beam appear.
The narrator doesn't know who these new searchers are.
They spread out, moving towards the rose garden.
The narrator feels like he's in a nightmare.
The garden's terraced structure makes descending difficult.
The trellises and thorny vines seem to writhe.
The night has become a waking nightmare.
The narrator's heart pounds, and he feels the sky might collapse.
He reaches a seven-foot iron fence at the garden's end and collides with it.
He crouches behind the fence, his mouth tasting bitter.
He feels thorns in his face, likely from the roses.
The scent of roses is overpowering, mixed with sweat and sunscreen.
He humorously considers the hunters tracking him by scent.
He observes the search party ascending the terraces.
The searchers are moving faster.
The narrator crosses the fence into a wide, dark valley with scattered oak trees.
The grass is tall due to recent rain.
He needs to get beyond the flashlight beams.
He runs further from the city, increasing his isolation.
He wishes the grass would conceal his tracks.
He reaches dense brush and a ten-foot-wide dry drainage ditch.

concepts.name: Certain

concepts.context: Fifteen years ago, fifteen years later, fifteen years before.

concepts.name: Ugly
concepts.context: Search for ugly, horrible, and frightening things.

concepts.name: Expect
concepts.context: I don't remember what we expected.

concepts.name: Weird
concepts.context: Bobby said we were weird kids, Narrator didn't think he was that weird.

concepts.name: Boy
concepts.context: Other boys, thirteen-year-old boys, boy's age, boy's morbid fascination.

concepts.name: Worse
concepts.context: Seemed to get worse as we got older.

concepts.name: Compare
concepts.context: Compared to other boys, comparing goosebumps.

concepts.name: Embrace
concepts.context: The more we admitted and embraced our oddness.

concepts.name: Forget
concepts.context: They forgot to close the louvers.

concepts.name: Miss
concepts.context: Would not want to miss the opportunity.

concepts.name: Long illness
concepts.context: Died from a long struggle with illness.

concepts.name: Acquaintance
concepts.context: Even if he were an acquaintance.

concepts.name: Fulfill
concepts.context: Satisfy the morbid entertainment and fantasies.

concepts.name: Pride
concepts.context: We took pride in being thirteen.

concepts.name: Striking
concepts.context: Most striking, most incredible, most marvelous.

concepts.name: Fascinated
concepts.context: We were fascinated by that eye.

concepts.name: Quietly
concepts.context: Sometimes we just sat there, quietly terrified.

concepts.name: Warm
concepts.context: The room must have been warm.

concepts.name: White smoke
concepts.context: Our breath did not form white smoke.

concepts.name: Old age
concepts.context: The ravages of old age and fatal illness.

concepts.name: Enjoyed
concepts.context: We enjoyed 'Night of the Living Dead'.

concepts.name: Cardboard box
concepts.context: Put the body into a cardboard box.

concepts.name: Squeeze
concepts.context: He squeezed the back of my neck.

concepts.name: Close
concepts.context: Frank Cork closed the furnace door.

concepts.name: Bleachers
concepts.context: Outdoor bleachers of a high school football field.

concepts.name: Cool
concepts.context: It was so cool, It was the coolest, cooler than.

concepts.name: Tanker truck
concepts.context: Exploding tanker truck on the highway.

concepts.name: Ranch
concepts.context: Zack Blenheim being gored by a bull.

concepts.name: Blood
concepts.context: Blood, eye filled with blood, bleeding eye.

concepts.name: Bond
concepts.context: An unbreakable bond, cemented our bond.

concepts.name: Friendship
concepts.context: Friendship, Bobby and I were friends, our friendship, our friendship was solidified.

concepts.name: Two years
concepts.context: We had been friends for two years.

concepts.name: Complex
concepts.context: More complex than it had been.

concepts.name: Profound
concepts.context: Its profundity was beyond our comprehension.

concepts.name: December
concepts.context: Second week of December, December night.

concepts.name: Peace of mind
concepts.context: Could no longer afford to trespass with peace of mind.

concepts.name: Back
concepts.context: Back at the crematorium window, back to the original departure point, narrator looks back.

concepts.name: Face
concepts.context: Bringing my face close to the window.

concepts.name: See
concepts.context: See everything that was going on inside.

concepts.name: Assistant
concepts.context: Frank Cork and his assistant, Sandy and his assistant, Jesse Pinne.

concepts.name: Body bag
concepts.context: Nylon body bag, narrator checks the body bag.

concepts.name: Cremated
concepts.context: To be cremated, bodies were cremated.

concepts.name: Five feet ten inches
concepts.context: Approximate height of the homeless man.

concepts.name: One hundred sixty pounds
concepts.context: Approximate weight of the homeless man.

concepts.name: Face
concepts.context: His whole face was beaten in.

concepts.name: Clotted
concepts.context: Eyes were covered with clotted blood.

concepts.name: Holes
concepts.context: The holes where his eyes had been.

concepts.name: Ivy
concepts.context: Afraid of tripping on the ivy.

concepts.name: Forever
concepts.context: Forever associate that scent with death.

concepts.name: Sigh
concepts.context: Bobby and I would always sigh.

concepts.name: Wet work
concepts.context: Where they did their wet work.

concepts.name: Daytime
concepts.context: Frank usually did the embalming during the daytime.

concepts.name: Nighttime
concepts.context: Cremations were always done at nighttime.

concepts.name: Possible
concepts.context: Made it impossible for us to participate.

concepts.name: High temperature
concepts.context: Capable of handling remains at a high temperature.

concepts.name: Exhaust system
concepts.context: Claimed to have an exhaust system.

concepts.name: Respect
concepts.context: Out of respect for the deceased's family and friends.

concepts.name: Mountain
concepts.context: Looking up from the valley floor.

concepts.name: Gray smoke
concepts.context: Into a wisp of gray smoke.

concepts.name: Convenient
concepts.context: It was very convenient for us.

concepts.name: Editor
concepts.context: Editor of the Moonlight Bay Gazette.

concepts.name: Familiarity
concepts.context: And his familiarity with the paper.

concepts.name: Accidental
concepts.context: News of accidental and natural deaths.

concepts.name: Fresh
concepts.context: As soon as Frank got a fresh corpse.

concepts.name: Determine
concepts.context: Couldn't determine whether he would embalm or cremate.

concepts.name: Cycle
concepts.context: As soon as the sun went down.

concepts.name: Sneak
concepts.context: Sneak onto the funeral home's private grounds.

concepts.name: Certain
concepts.context: Until we were certain he wouldn't be cremated.

concepts.name: Witness
concepts.context: Did not witness the process, witness the cremation.

concepts.name: Weight
concepts.context: Held a place in our hearts.

concepts.name: Understand
concepts.context: We understood she was a beautiful woman.

concepts.name: Appreciate
concepts.context: We didn't appreciate this quiet, rain-like beauty.

concepts.name: Attract
concepts.context: Only the hot, nude women on poker cards attracted us.

concepts.name: Notice
concepts.context: Never paid much attention to her.

concepts.name: Trace
concepts.context: Death left no trace on her face.

concepts.name: Artery
concepts.context: Defect in the wall of a brain artery.

concepts.name: Smile
concepts.context: Corners of her mouth turned up.

concepts.name: Thought
concepts.context: Without a hint of carnal thought.

concepts.name: Behind her
concepts.context: The furnace door closed behind her.

concepts.name: Wipe
concepts.context: Wiped the corners of his eyes.

concepts.name: Feathers
concepts.context: City lights shimmered like a phoenix's colorful feathers.

concepts.name: Shimmering
concepts.context: Lapping waves churned, creating shimmering crests.

concepts.name: Collapse
concepts.context: And collapsed from right to left.

concepts.name: Peel
concepts.context: Like a strip of white skin.

concepts.name: Black flesh
concepts.context: Peeling from the sea's black flesh.

concepts.name: Christmas
concepts.context: Christmas was two weeks away, David's Christmas.

concepts.name: Wonder
concepts.context: I wondered what Bobby was thinking.

concepts.name: Understand
concepts.context: He probably didn't understand what death was.

concepts.name: Sure
concepts.context: He would know what death was.

concepts.name: Decorate
concepts.context: Would he still put up a Christmas tree for David?

concepts.name: Heart
concepts.context: Where would he find the heart?

concepts.name: Tinsel
concepts.context: To twine tinsel around the branches.

concepts.name: Swim
concepts.context: Let's go swimming, narrator and Bobby swim, narrator feels he shouldn't swim.

concepts.name: Warm
concepts.context: No warm currents from the southern hemisphere.

concepts.name: Uninviting
concepts.context: The temperature of the water was uninviting.

concepts.name: Kelp
concepts.context: On a pile of dry, tangled kelp.

concepts.name: Lay
concepts.context: Laid my own clothes beside his.

concepts.name: Far
concepts.context: A good distance from the shore.

concepts.name: Throat
concepts.context: Scoured our precious body heat from our throats.

concepts.name: Biting
concepts.context: Biting us with their icy white foam.

concepts.name: Lost
concepts.context: Not letting each other out of sight.

concepts.name: Comfort
concepts.context: No comfort from the winter night sky.

concepts.name: Rescue
concepts.context: Would save each other without question.

concepts.name: Spit
concepts.context: We spat the bitter taste of the sea.

concepts.name: Warm
concepts.context: How hot the cremator's fire was.

concepts.name: Park
concepts.context: Through the parkland bordering the beach.

concepts.name: Home
concepts.context: Rode off to our respective homes.

concepts.name: Hesitate
concepts.context: Bobby and I would still unhesitatingly.

concepts.name: Sensory
concepts.context: Things we can perceive with our senses.

concepts.name: Touch
concepts.context: Things we can't touch, taste, smell, or see.

concepts.name: Bike
concepts.context: Bicycles and the boys who ride them.

concepts.name: Imagination
concepts.context: As real as things in our imagination.

concepts.name: Endure
concepts.context: Emotions that endure longer than the world.

concepts.name: Thought
concepts.context: More real than I had imagined.

concepts.name: Brutally
concepts.context: Someone had brutally beaten a hitchhiker to death.

concepts.name: Body swap
concepts.context: In order to facilitate a body swap with my father's corpse.

concepts.name: Reason
concepts.context: What was the reason for gouging out his eyes?

concepts.name: Sent
concepts.context: Sent to the furnace without eyes.

concepts.name: Purely
concepts.context: Purely for the thrill of base depravity?

concepts.name: Harsh
concepts.context: Harsh rasp of a rusty knife.

concepts.name: Enjoy
concepts.context: A person like that could certainly enjoy inflicting pain.

concepts.name: Guilty
concepts.context: I shrank away from the window, guiltily.

concepts.name: Alarm
concepts.context: As if I'd tripped some kind of alarm.

concepts.name: Closer
concepts.context: When I moved closer to the window again.

concepts.name: Wall
concepts.context: Picked up the telephone receiver from the wall.

concepts.name: Hear
concepts.context: Couldn't hear what he was saying.

concepts.name: Machine
concepts.context: Almost knocking the whole telephone machine off the wall.

concepts.name: Other end
concepts.context: Whoever was on the other end.

concepts.name: Ears
concepts.context: Must have had his ears ringing.

concepts.name: Dislike
concepts.context: Did not sound appreciative or affectionate.

concepts.name: Begin
concepts.context: Began zipping up the body bag.

concepts.name: Cover
concepts.context: To cover the homeless man's corpse.

concepts.name: Hook
concepts.context: On a hook on the right-hand door.

concepts.name: Fumble
concepts.context: Pinne was still fumbling with the bag.

concepts.name: Seen
concepts.context: I guessed I hadn't been seen.

concepts.name: Creak
concepts.context: Crisp sound of crushed snail shells.

concepts.name: Tracker
concepts.context: Mask the footsteps of a tracker.

concepts.name: Sure
concepts.context: I was sure the call had come.

concepts.name: Inspect
concepts.context: Inspected the contents of the briefcase.

concepts.name: Conclude
concepts.context: Concluded I must have been to the garage.

concepts.name: Simple
concepts.context: Not as simple as he thought.

concepts.name: Look
concepts.context: See if I was still lurking nearby.

concepts.name: Expansive
concepts.context: Seemed more expansive than I remembered.

concepts.name: Dare
concepts.context: I didn't dare cross the courtyard.

concepts.name: Linger
concepts.context: Not to linger near the house or the driveway.

concepts.name: Risk
concepts.context: The risk of going back the way I came.

concepts.name: Fast
concepts.context: Ran as fast as I could.

concepts.name: Heel
concepts.context: Dug my heels into the soft earth.

concepts.name: Bitterness
concepts.context: A bitter taste in my mouth.

concepts.name: Felt
concepts.context: Reached up and felt my face.

concepts.name: Thorns
concepts.context: Three thorns had stuck into the flesh.

concepts.name: Smell
concepts.context: Could smell the scent of my sunscreen.

concepts.name: Scent
concepts.context: Track me by scent like hounds.

concepts.name: Ascending
concepts.context: Ascending from the top terrace to the second.

concepts.name: Dinosaur
concepts.context: Looked like the bones of a dinosaur.

concepts.name: Crushed
concepts.context: Crushed blades of grass beneath my shoes.

concepts.name: Sure
concepts.context: I was sure Sandy's gang wouldn't miss a square inch.

concepts.name: Reach
concepts.context: Before they reached the iron fence.

concepts.name: Out of range
concepts.context: Beyond the reach of the flashlights.

concepts.name: Further
concepts.context: The further I ran from the city.

concepts.name: Season
concepts.context: Lucky to have hit this season.

concepts.name: Golden
concepts.context: Tall grass would have been golden.

concepts.name: Track
concepts.context: My passage would have left a visible track.

concepts.name: Slope
concepts.context: At the bottom of the slope.

concepts.name: Dry

main_topics: Journey to the Funeral Home and Sandy Cork's Deception
The Narrator's Childhood Exploration of the Crematorium
The Present Visit and the Unveiling of Brutality
hierarchy.structure: The document begins with an immediate event (the phone call) and then flashes back to establish context and past experiences. The narrative then returns to the present, detailing the narrator's investigation and subsequent flight. The structure blends present action with significant flashbacks to build suspense and thematic depth.
